div.p: piecing out marble with stucco, which was freq the stucco parts have perished in the course of tion in which these heads belong, have been tr of a somewhat similar head, or rather mask, t vincingly, by modern restorers 2. In the absenc of the Pompeian head when found and the me possibility at least may be suggested, -and I b that its noble locks, certainly Greek in feeling representation of the Father of Gods and Men In my previous article 3, attention was called to the scanty remains of a great ment inscription which once ran from the west to the east side of the Forum. Its sions were impressive. The height of the letter Q, still in situ, there published, is and its width, exclusive of the tail, is m. 0.32. The second letter, on a relaid slab , L but E, and is preserved for only about its lower half, the stone having been cut that point; a bit of the right end protuberance of the middle hasta is visible, as w observed by Miss A. Frantz of the party from the American Academy in Rome w ited Pompeii in March 1925; the preserved portion measures m. 0.13 in height, an intact this letter may well have equalled the height of the Q; the width of the bo is m. 0.155. The slab of pavement still in situ, with the Q, measures m. 3.12 X 1 Journal of Hellenic Studies, XLII, 1922, pp. 31-35. 2 G. DICKINS, Hellenistic Sculpture, p. 24, however, thought that some of the ancient stucco additions to this example were still visible; he added to this general class of head one from Nemi, now in Nottingham Castle (WALLIS,Catalogue,no. 832).

I have been unable to convince myself of the correctness of Dickins's observation with regard to the Otricoli Zeus; in its present state it would not be possible to be sure of all details without a thorough cleaning of the surface and practically a microscopic examination; but my own observations are as follows:
The whole back of the head, and the back part of the locks, except at the base, is modern, and of stucco.

As to the locks above the upper, left part of the God's face, which are probably those meant by Dickins, it is not possible to affirm positively that they are not of stucco; I believe however that they are of marble, original, and broken off from the main block; there is a modern patch of marble at the left temple.

Of marble and of one piece with the face is the inner part of the God's right group of curls, for the entire side of the face. The rest of the outer portion of the locks, on both sides of the face, is modern and I believe of marble;
this includes the extreme left side of the face. All the beard is original, of marble, and of one piece with the face.

The upper left eyelid and the tip of the nose are restored in marble, and the neck, bust, drapery, and the lower part of the locks, are also modern marble work. There has apparently also been considerable cleaning of the original surface, and I think some piecing out and smearing with stucco or other preparations on parts of the modern marble as well.
Very noticeable is the difference in spirit between the ancient and the modern portions of the locks of hair.
3 Pages 70 f.

4 Page 71, note 3; I am credibly informed that this piece was formerly kept in the storerooms of the excavation, whence it was brought to its present place. 5 This is in accordance with the usual practice at the beginning of the Empire, as observed by AEM. HUEBNER, Exempla Scr. Epigr. Lat., p. LX.

The cutting for another of its letters can be slabs of worn limestone pavement now stored in a house near the Forum, Reg. VIII, Ins. iii, No. 31. The letter is a V; its bottom is b intact it must have measured not far from m. 0.30 in height; i mensions which correspond exactly with those of the Q, and at le those of the E. The cutting for the V is on a slab m. 0.25 thick an has been broken starting from the lower part of the letter, but height; what appears to be a chipped corner of the top of the slab tance from this to the top of the V is almost exactly one meter; w the bottom of the slab still in situ to the foot of the Q is likewise The agreement in dimensions seems conclusive for assigning all t the same monumental inscription. My friend the Ingegnere L. Iacono, whose keen observation well known, kindly informs me that he has discovered still anoth scription. It is to be seen in the extreme right intercolumniation (a of the Capitolium, in a broken slab which was used in a restorati Iacono considers ancient. There is preserved the upper part of if it is the other half of the second letter, described above. III. -THE ORIGINAL PORTA MARINA AND THE ADJACENT PORTION OF THE CITY WALL. The manuals recognise quite correctly that the present form of the Porta Marina due, first to the rebuilding of the gate proper in the second century B. C., and then t addition of the inner rooms and the long arched passage probably in the early yea Sulla's colony; the remains of private structures immediately outside the gate nat date from the last period before the eruption. This leads to a consideration of the theory developed by A. Sogliano 3, that t originally no entrance at the Porta d'Ercolano, and none in fact at that point derstand his meaning -earlier than the present structure. The latter supposition is not tenable in view of the evidence afforded partly by the alignment of certa outside the gate, and still more by the manner in which the well-built stone str the wall is interrupted: the original gate lay a few feet further to the west than t 1 Rendiconti dei Lincei, Classe Scienze Mor., Stor. e Fil., Ser. V, vol. XXII, 1913, pp. 275-279. 2 Pomp. Studien, pp. 458, 466. 3 Naples, Atti, Nuova Ser., VI, 1918, i, pp. 158 f. Besides, the presence of an extensive Samnite necropolis and left of the highway as one goes from the Porta d'Ercolano a strong presumption in the same sense. While we do not possess the elements for appraising the d this point, still the above-mentioned evidence for the presence times tends seriously to weaken the force of Sogliano's theory2 of the city: namely, that the cardo was the Strada Stabiana, an Nolana (for which he assumes a gate at the west end as we east) and the Strada dell'Abbondanza. When writing his article anist did not have access to my proposal 3 to recognise in the degli Augustali, and the southern part of the Strada Stabiana, t dating the Etruscan town-plan; I once more recommend this su of scholars, in the belief that it offers the solution of severa light on early conditions at this site. My suggestion that th Etruscan cardo had of course been advanced before, as the ide appears to have rejected it because the north end of this stre not a gate, in the city wall; and he might have added that th end either; but it should be remembered that both the tower t the south date from a period far later than that with which builders of the tower would have chosen the position as command

If there was originally a gate at each end of this cardo, topog have made it ceremonial or decorative rather than utilitarian would have been for it to fall into neglect and eventually to b in imagining this is certainly no greater than that involved i the western end of the Strada di Nola .
V. -THE APSE ARCH OF THE K OFFICES OF THE DUOVIRI ,.

The easternmost of the three public buildings at the south end of the Forum is no conspicuous for the high arch, in large part preserved 6, which separates its apse from Pompeii. Repeated and careful ocular observation from the ground, at intervals of six months or a year, has convinced me that it showed a normal form of semicircular arch, consisting of two concentric half-circles of tiles, the outer set of which however was not solid but merely faced the two surfaces of the wall. The inner series of tiles has been uniformly removed or destroyed, probably by the survivors of the catastrophe, who discovered that there lay here ready to their hand a quantity of large pieces of tile suitable for use in their own building operations. The photograph (P1. 59, Fig. 1) shows that this operation has exposed the concrete body of the concavity of the arch, as distinguished from its facing of tiles; if we allow one foot or more for the tiles that were once in position, the result will be the original circle which took up the lines of the wall-ends on which the arch rests. The circle of tiles which is seen at present consists of the original second circle, which reinforced the circle now lost, but on the surfaces only of the walls; below the springing of the arch, the facing-tiles of the walls were hacked away to an amount of fifteen courses on the east wall and fourteen courses on the west wall.

The result has been to give the impression to the spectator that the curve of the arch was continued for more than 1800, that is to say, that we have here a ((horse-shoe arch )); and in fact this has been called the earliest known example of the type to be found in Italy'.

That this was not however the intention of the makers appears to be established by the observations summarised above. The peculiar plan of this structure is shown in the handbooks 2; there is a symm arrangement of the large curved niche and the two small rectangular ones on each the great door. Our Plate, 59, Fig. 2 uniform positions over the brick surface, as well as traces of marble wedges for attachment, show that the whole front sur with marble; at the bases in the niches, the bronze inscriptio to this marble surface.

As is known, the excavators found these four small niches inscriptions testify to two personages who were here comme from the left (of the spectator) contained a statue of Romulus, of the elogium of that hero was discovered where it had fallen inscription of Aeneas was found in many fragments, scattere there is no evidence as to which niche the corresponding stat
The traditional statement in archaeological publications, th Vill. -PARALLELS TO VARRO'S AVIARY.

The learned Varro's account of the aviary which he built for his villa at Casin is sufficiently precise to admit of a reconstruction on paper I which I believe to be cohe and attractive; it would be interesting to see the results of a more material reconstruct which might afford considerable pleasure to some bird-lover with a historical bent of m When occupied with this matter, I noticed one instance, namely the well-known paint from the ((Villa of Julia Felix 2, where some of Varro's motives could be paralleled fr an approximately contemporary Pompeian monument; and since that time I have m tained a receptive attitude toward further parallels, which have not been lacking.

The Villa of Diomed affords a splendid instance of several of the elements of Var aviary: a large rectangular area, surrounded by porticoes, in the axis of which there i pool and a pergula adapted for banquets: in this case the dining room was not on an is in the pool, but adjoining the latter.
In the large house with garden recently excavated on the S. side of the Strada dell' bondanza is a combination of waterworks and pools with triclinium.

VI. i. 7 (Casa delle Vestali), in the furthest peristyle, near the city wall, is fir narrow tank, and then a square, deep pool with a square island in the middle, the of which, except for a strip about the edges, is depressed as if to contain running wa

The house VI. ix. 6 (Casa di Castore e Polluce) has in its Southern part a peris within which is a large rectangular pool, in the center of which is the base for some s ture; and also a smaller rectangular tank3.

VI. -THE FOUR SMALL NICHES IN THE CHALCIDICUM OF THE BUILDING OF EUMACHIA.

, shows the portion of the wall to the north o door. The small niches measure m. 1.15 in width, and their depth to the back wall is about m. 0.50. The peculiarity of their plan -a shallow base behind, and a tripartite arrangement in front-is probably due to the necessity of affixing the bronze inscriptions in the position now occupied by the cast of the elogium of Romulus, as shown in the picture, while at the same time a statue was to be placed upon the base.There are clear traces that the back walls of the niches were veneered with slabs of marble; hence we cannot think of reliefs in this position. Holes for nails which recur at already destroyed at the time of excavation; it doubtless protruded above ground in the period immediately following the eruption. 1 E. T. DEWALD, in Amer. Romulus, and probably Julius Caesar and Augustus, were repr left to right, rests on no evidence except in the case of Romu of Aeneas is not fixed, and the presence of statues of Caesar thetical. In fact, the inclusion of these two latter personages in the first place, no fragments of inscriptions in their hono cinity, and beside, the archetypes of the class of elogia to whi and Romulus belong, namely those erected by Augustus in Ro temple of Mars Ultor 4, did not include Caesar and August is there reason for supposing that these rulers were later inser of which was to commemorate the worthies of olden days and resentatives of the Julian house. Another arrangement seems appropriate and not improbable to right): (1) Roma, who required no inscription for identific the relative inscription commemorates as the founder of Rom scription states, led the Trojan survivors to Italy; and (4) Italia the identification of which no inscription was needed. This in the spirit of the Ara Pacis Augustae, if the signification of developed by me in Journal of Roman Studies, III, 1913, pp C. I. L., X, 808, 809. 2 G. FIORELLI, Descrizione di Pompei, p. 258. 3 L. c.; see also AVELLINO, in Bull. Nap., III, 1845, p.35. ' C. I. L., I, ed. 2, pp. 183-197.5 There are extant two elogia of Caesar the grandfather and Octavius the father respectively of Augustus (C. I. L., I, ed. 2, p. 199, nos. XXVIII, XXIX); but they do not belong in the same group with the others, as is shown by their provenance and the style in which the second one is composed; of the first only a fragment has been transmitted. It is to be hoped that the government excavations now in progress about the temple of Mars Ultor will result in additions to our repertory of elogia. If the report is true that an elogium of Julius Caesar's father has already been discovered, this would bring the official series down to what in the Augustan age was a comparatively recent past but still beyond the memory of all but the very oldest among the living. A special appropriateness would have been disco of Romulus and Aeneas in the entrance hall of Augustan house which are commemorated in the are concordia and pietas, qualities which our liter respectively with the institutions of the found Trojan wanderer 2. In fact, we may go further and niches contained statues of Concordia and Pietas VII. -MARKS OF THE SULLAN BOMBARDMENT. The amount of attention which various features in Pompeii have excited, both amo tourists and in the world of scholarship, is not always proportionate to their intrinsic s nificance. For some reason, a matter which the successive groups of scholars who have v ited the site under my guidance have felt to be one of the most impressive memorials the place's history has remained practically unnoticed3: namely, the numerous marks t be seen on the exterior of the town wall and apparently due to the operations of the tro of the Sullan party who, as appears from OROSIUS V, xviii, 22, laid siege to Pompei the year 89 B. C. The marks in question fall into three classes, large, intermediate and small, the ameter of the large ones being in general about m. 0.14; of the intermediate ones, m. 0 to 0.08; and of the small ones, m. 0.01 to 0.02. Some at least of these are due, in m opinion, to the impact respectively of balls from ballistae and shot from slings: the imp from these missiles would have pulverised a certain area of the surface of the stone the wall, which area may well have varied somewhat with the force of impact 4. These marks are found in large numbers along a stretch of the walls extending som 100 feet to the west of the Porta di Vesuvio (Plate 60, fig. 1), terminating at a port which was rebuilt in rubble in antiquity; and also for some 25 feet to the east of the Por 1 Livy, 1, xiii, 8, Inde non modo commune sed concors etiam regnum duobus regibus fuit; DIONYS. HAL., Il, xi. 2: ovrw 66 a'ea fEfato; 'v , 'Pwjoiav 6,uvota zjv 4eXiv En T6V vno 'Puviov maTao,evaaOvrcov Aapoi5aa '66ov, 2 VERGIL, Aen., passim. 3 I recollect having seen a casual reference to it in an official publication; and I have been told that it is also mentioned in a popular guide; but I have been unable to verify either reference for the present purpose. I My good friend Dr. M. Della Corte of the Administration of the Excavations at Pompeii has been so kind as to contribute the following observations: the holes are curving, show no signs of chiselling or tool work, and are found on different parts of the face of the stones so that they are not to be interpreted as cramps or dowel holes. In his opinion they were caused by some instrument of percussion, probably an aries with a metallic head. This content downloaded from 46.124.163.71 on Fri, 05 Dec 2025 22:58:09 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms FURTHER STUDIES IN POMPEIAN ARCHAEOLOGY III d'Ercolano; the space between these two points was partly resto partly concealed by volcanic ejecta etc., and one cannot say if it als but it is clear from the lie of the land that an attacking party w forts on the vicinity of the Porta di Vesuvio, as being the highest of wall and the spot where the aqueduct entered the city; while t Porta d'Ercolano was dominated by the ground outside and to the have encouraged an assault at that point as well.

Again, the fascination exercised on the Romans by the sight of little birds flutte about and alighting on the brackets projecting from columns, one of the features of V aviary, is suggested by several Pompeian paintings which are reproduced in the monum publication, Le Case ed i Monumenti di Pompei Disegnati e Descritti. These are ent in the Third Style, with the exception of the first to be enumerated, which belongs to I A. W. VAN BUREN and R. M. KENNEDY in journ. of Rom. Stud., IX, 1919, 59-66. 2 A. MAU, Gesch. d. Dec. Wandmalerei in Pompeii, p. 178, pl. VII b. 3 Plate 60, Fig. 2 (ALINARI, No. 11349), looking West. Second Style: this then is contemporary with V in period. Some of these are frankly fantasti starting-point was surely in the realm of realit Vol. IV, Nuovi Scavi, Tav. XVI, from the Ca architectural reality and shows, not birds, but a might have suggested Varro's brackets.
Vol. III, Casa di (L. Cecilio) Giocondo, Tav. II, spring from columns: on them however we find Vol. IV, Nuovi Scavi, Tav. XV, a house of Re with birds alighting on their cup-like ledges.
More fantastic in treatment of both volutes a and the left panel of Tav. LIII.

In the central panel of Tav. LXV and the central panel of Tav. LXXXVII, we see ornate arrangements of foliage, doubtless with a basis of box: here the birds are alighting on the volutes, and in the second painting the same purpose is served by some of the leaves as well: here the wall-painter has reproduced some manifestations of the topiary's art where its achievements were closest to nature itself.
IX. -ORIENTATION.

It is generally agreed that the town-plan of Pompeii as we now have it is d can engineers of the fifth century B. C. I am not aware that an attempt h to explain why these engineers did not give their city a proper north and south but drew their cardo in such a manner that the observer standing at the east forum and looking up the Strada di Mercurio finds his line of vision turned a of the distance from the North toward the West; while the direction of t the quarter lying to the east of the Strada Stabiana is turned still more towar of North.

The direction of the Strada Stabiana itself was probably determined by the existence of a depression at this part of the hill, furnishing a natural line of connection between the highest and the lowest points of the circuit. But I believe there was another reason for laying out the eastern streets parallel to this one, as well as for the alignment of the cardo and the series of streets which belong to the western system.
The interesting discussion which Vitruvius devotes (I, vi, 1-3) to the question of
